title: Clevedon to Weston-Super-Mare Walk Route

images.title: Salthouse Point, Clevedon by Brian Robert Marshall, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Salthouse Point, Clevedon

images.title: Sharon Loxton / Saltmarsh and the Severn Estuary
images.caption: Saltmarsh and the Severn Estuary. Grass covered mini mounds of mud have trapped all manner of items; plastic bottles, bricks, lumps of concrete to name but a few. Beyond the grassy area is the muddy saltmarsh and the Severn Estuary. The Severn Estuary is a Special Protection Area - European Marine Site. It has the second highest tidal range in the world at 12 metres. This tidal regime results in plant and animal communities typical of the extreme physical conditions of strong flows, mobile sediments, changing salinity, high turbidity and heavy scouring. The site is important in the spring and autumn migration periods for waders moving along the west coast of Europe, as well as in winter for large numbers of waterbirds including swans, geese, ducks and waders. These bird populations are regarded as internationally important.

images.title: High Tide at the Seawall near Clevedon by Ian Knox, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: High Tide at the Seawall near Clevedon

images.title: Sharon Loxton / Revetment to Rock armour
images.caption: Revetment to Rock armour. Sea defences along the Bristol Channel. In the foreground is revetment and beyond that it changes to rock armour. The black streak in the distance is the Blackstone Rocks.

images.title: John Thorn / Wick St Lawrence Wharf
images.caption: Wick St Lawrence Wharf. This Wharf was part of the Weston, Clevedon and Portishead Light Railway which closed in 1941. The river is the Yeo which flows from Blagdon to the Bristol Channel

images.title: Martin Bodman, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Wick St Lawrence

images.title: Adrian and Janet Quantock / Bridge at Ebdon
images.caption: Bridge at Ebdon

images.title: Birnbeck Pier by Neil Owen, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Birnbeck Pier

description: This walk takes you from Clevedon to Weston-Super-Mare using a mixture of coastal paths and country lanes. The walk starts on the coast at Clevedon where you can pick up the Poets Walk along the Bristol Channel. You continue south to Gullhouse Point along the sea wall, with fine coastal views to enjoy. You then leave the coast to follow pleasant country lanes, past the villages of Kingston Seymour, Hewish and Wick St Lawrence, crossing the River Yeo as you go. The walk then crosses the River Banwell at Ebdon before following tracks to the coast around Worlebury Hill and Weston Woods. The route then heads south of Sand Point, passing along Sand Bay before finishing in Weston on the sea front at Birnbeck Pier.
